docs.lead_paragraph: The therapeutic value of amusement parks has been largely overlooked by doctors. Until now. When the young man, 19, arrived at a hospital in Zurich, his right eye had an odd resemblance to the eye of a cat. The pupil had become a long, narrow vertical slit -- a result, he admitted, of a bar fight.

headline.main: Coaster Ride Gives Patient Extra Thrill

docs.abstract: Dr Michael Theil, University of Zurich eye surgeon, describes case history in which patient suffering from dislocated artificial eye lens had lens slip back into place from intense force of roller coaster ride; case appears in New England Journal of Medicine; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The room is filled with physicians from all over the country. It was silent until a few moments ago, when the first sad gasp was heard from the far corner. Now tearful faces fill the room. I've asked each doctor here to write a letter to a patient about something unresolved. The doctors will never mail these letters; instead, they have been instructed to write as openly and truthfully as they can.

headline.main: Beyond the Blame: A No-Fault Approach to Malpractice

docs.abstract: Dr Dan Shapiro, University of Arizona College of Medicine psychologist and author, holds that no-fault system of compensating patients for medical errors would be far superior to current and prevalent malpractice litigation; details how fear of malpractice often causes doctors to hide mistakes from patients; outlines possible process of reporting errors to commissions made up of patients and physicians and suggests ways system might deal with doctors, who continue to cover up their mistakes; recognizes that change to no-fault malpractice would not be easy to implement, but holds new system would be fair to both doctors and patients and provide better medical care; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Dr. Peter M. Meyer and his colleagues asked a large group of menopausal women how many of them were bothered by forgetfulness. ''Every hand in the room went up,'' he recalled. But tests conducted over several years turned up no evidence to support the idea that menopause actually interfered with memory, according to an article released yesterday.
docs.abstract: Dr Peter M Meyer and colleagues at Rush-Presbyterian-St Luke's Medical Center (Chicago) publish study in journal Neurology that finds no evidence of memory loss during or after menopause, despite overwhelming numbers of women who complain of forgetfulness (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to advertisements for the once-popular tonic Geritol, most people of a certain age know about ''tired blood,'' a disorder more accurately called anemia, involving a shortage of healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen to body tissues and cleanse them of carbon dioxide. It is not really the blood of people with anemia that is ''tired.'' Rather, it is anemic people themselves who commonly experience chronic fatigue. Other symptoms may include weakness, shortness of breath, impaired athletic performance, rapid heartbeat, irritability, apathy, dizziness, pale skin, headache and numb or cold hands and feet. But in many people the symptoms are too mild to be recognized and the anemia goes undetected for years.

headline.main: 'Tired Blood' Warning: Ignore It at Your Peril

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses common disorder of anemia, details those at risk and gives possible consequences of leaving condition untreated; Dr Allen R Nissenson, University of California (Los Angeles) nephrologist and medical professor, co-authors article in Archives of Internal Medicine that stresses need to take anemia seriously and actively test for condition; link between anemia and physical decline in elderly is debated; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The SARS outbreak in Toronto apparently caused men there to start washing their hands after using the bathroom, according to a new survey conducted for the American Society of Microbiology. Apart from Toronto, however, the figures collected by observers in airport bathrooms did not paint a very sanitary picture. In five American cities, only 70 percent of men and 80 percent of women washed their hands. The lowest percentage among men was found in Chicago (38 percent); among women, it was in San Francisco (41 percent). The survey was released at the society's conference in Chicago last week.

headline.main: The Filthy Truth About the Hands

docs.abstract: Study sponsored by American Society of Microbiology shows increase in hand washing in Toronto (Canada) during SARS outbreak there; Dr Judy A Dale, University of Utah microbiologist, reports hand washing soared to 96 percent for both men and women from 70 percent of men and 80 percent of women observed elsewhere; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Adding behavioral teaching techniques to a rehabilitation program led to significant improvement for stroke and brain injury victims trying to regain use of their limbs, a study released yesterday found. In three weeks of daily 90-minute sessions using behavioral techniques, 13 young patients with chronic movement restrictions improved the use of the affected limbs from poor to fair, according to the study, which was published in the journal Neurology. Three weeks of prior conventional occupational therapy had produced little or no change.

headline.main: Tiny Goals Can Yield Big Gains

docs.abstract: Dr Annette Sterr, University of Liverpool researcher, leads study published in journal Neurology that supports use of method called constraint-induced movement therapy, or CIT, to treat patients suffering movement difficulties brought on by brain injury or stroke; exercises involve pinning working limbs close to body of patient and working on small specific movement goals for impaired limbs; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two new studies have found that teaching older people how to relax or manage stress can result in measurable improvements in the ability of their immune systems to protect them from infection. In one study, released yesterday, 31 people over 60 were tested to gauge their defenses against shingles, which grows more common and more debilitating with age.

headline.main: A Lesson for the Immune System

docs.abstract: Two studies, one published in journal Psychosomatic Medicine and one led by researchers at University of Bristol and published in journal Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics, show that stress reduction in older people can result in better immune system functioning and protection from infection; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Casts come in many colors these days, but Audrey Jessup, 13, had no trouble picking out one for her broken arm last week. A friend and soccer teammate already had a bright pink cast for the same kind of break, so Audrey chose bright pink, too. ''It was good having somebody around who was having the same experience,'' Audrey said.

headline.main: Finding Just the Right Cast, as Fractures Increase

docs.abstract: Mayo Clinic study, published last week in Journal of American Medical Assn, finds sharp increase in number of forearm fractures in children from 1969 to 2001; fractures rose 52 percent for girls and 32 percent for boys; two different reasons for this increase are explored; Mayo Clinic researcher Dr Sundeep Khosla holds that inadequate nutrition is to blame for weakened bones in children; Dr Jordan D Metzl, Sports Medicine Institute for Young Athletes at Hospital for Special Surgery (NYC) medical director, contends that growth of competitive sports is linked with bone injuries; cites need for preventative measures such as weight training for young athletes; photo (M)
